items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees.  Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit of $83,400 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts and purchase orders for the period of February 10, 2013 through March 9, 2013 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to the CCCT Board Governing Policies, the election of members of the CCCT board of the League will take place between March 10 and April 25. This year there are seven, three-year vacancies on the board.
	 
Each member community college district board of the League shall have one vote for each of the seven vacancies on the CCCT board. Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The seven candidates who receive the most votes will serve three-year terms. In the event of a tie vote for the last position to be filled, the CCCT board will vote to break the tie.
	 
The fifteen trustees who have been nominated for election to the board are listed on the attached document sheet in the Secretary of State's random drawing order. An official ballot for the election is also attached, which will record the seven candidates chosen by the Board of Trustees at the meeting.  The ballot will then be signed by the Board President and Board Secretary and mailed to the CCCT Elections Committee.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees choose seven of fifteen candidates nominated to serve on the California Community College Trustees Board.

items.item_details:
Each year many community colleges project negative cash flows in some months and must engage in temporary borrowing in order to ensure that unrestricted funds are available to meet payroll and other operational expenses.  For many years the California Community College League has coordinated an effort to pool the cash needs of these districts by issuing one debt instrument for all districts.  This provides substantial savings in the cost of going to market with short-term debt instruments.  The cost of the Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note to the District is estimated to be approximately $54,000; however, will be partially offset by the short-term investment earnings that the District will realize while the cash is deposited in the County's investment pool.
	 
The Fiscal Services Department has completed an initial projection of the District's unrestricted cash flow for Fiscal Year 2013-2014.  It is anticipated that the District will experience a negative unrestricted cash balance during the second quarter of Fiscal Year 2013-2014.  Adoption of this resolution will mitigate the deficit cash balance and provide a prudent cash balance throughout Fiscal Year 2013-2014.
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the attached resolution in order for the District to participate in the pooled TRANS program.  The initial projection of the District's unrestricted cash flow for Fiscal Year 2013-2014 is attached separately.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt a resolution authorizing the borrowing of funds for Fiscal Year 2013-2014 in an amount not to exceed $7,000,000 through the issuance and sale of a Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note (TRAN) by participating in the Community College League of California Tax and Revenue Anticipation Notes Program.
items.item_text: FY2013-2014 Issuance of Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note (TRAN)
items.item_text_raw: 4. FY2013-2014 Issuance of Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note (TRAN)

items.item_details:
Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) Revision 001 â HMC ARCHITECTS - Professional Services for District  Information Technology Design Standards & Contract Extension
	 
It is typical for a District to develop design standards for various and certain products and systems. SJECCD does not have a consolidated set of design standards.  An effort in early 2011 was made to identify the prevalent materials used on each campus, but that information needs to be developed further to be useful in ensuring that certain minimum standards are met in the design and construction of future projects.
	 
On October 9, 2012 the Board approved an ICA to HMC Architects (HMC) in the amount of $245,000 for professional services to prepare District Design Standards.  These Design Standards will be used for all future projects District-wide and will be germane to each campus as applicable.  At the time the ICA was issued, it did not include standards for Information Technology as this portion of the scope was anticipated to be managed separately. The District has since determined that, due to time constraints and in the interest of economy, the Information Technology Standards should be developed in concert with the development of the balance of the design standards by HMC Architects. HMC was requested to prepare a proposal to add this effort to their scope.  Based on the proposal received and negotiated, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Revision #01 to the ICA with HMC to prepare design standards for Information Technology, and to extend the schedule for deliverables to accommodate the additional scope of work to June 30, 2014.  
                                               
HMC Architects ICA contract value          $245,000
HMC Architects ICA revision 001             $  22,900
	 
Revised contract total                               $267,900
	 
	 
The Board is asked to approve Revision #001 to the ICA with HMC ARCHITECTS  for professional services to establish Information Technology Standards as part of the District Design Standards in the amount of $22,900 and to extend the term of the ICA to June 30, 2014.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of Revision 001 to the ICA with HMC ARCHITECTS for professional services to establish information Technology Standards as part of the District Design Standards in the amount of $22,900 and to extend the term of the ICA to June 30, 2014.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010: Revision #1 to the ICA with HMC Architects for Technology Design Standards
items.item_text_raw: 5. Measure G-2010: Revision #1 to the ICA with HMC Architects for Technology Design Standards

items.item_details:
In November 2011 the Board approved the 2025 Facility Master Plan for EVC.  At that time $5.7M was established as the conceptual construction budget for the building and associated sitework.  Based on a proposal and interview competition, Lionakis was selected by a panel of District and College faculty and staff. The Board approved a contract with Lionakis on May 08, 2012 to provide design and construction administration services for the EVC Automotive Technology project.  At that time the college understood that an appropriate Automotive Technology facility might require more funding than had been originally allocated for construction and agreed to defer any adjustments to the budget until a final program for the facility was completed and approved. Thus the original Lionakis contract includes a fixed price for programming and a percentage fee for design based on the original conceptual construction budget of $5.7M. The final College approved program indicated a probable cost of construction of $8,842,798. Based on this, the project budget, and bond list, was revised and approved by the Board on December 11, 2012. This adjustment to project scope and budget warrants a corresponding adjustment to the design agreement with Lionakis in accordance with the contract terms, in the amount of $259,281.
	 
In addition, the original contract provided for analysis of sustainable strategies (supporting LEED Silver certification) for the project through programming.  With the programming complete and the sustainable strategies identified, the design effort necessary to design and certify specific components into the project needs to be added.  This component of the Lionakis proposal, reviewed by the college and Gilbane, is valued at an additional $61,534.
	 
Lionakis PAA EVC-01Contract Value  $668,350
Lionakis design services based on revised construction cost  ADD $259,281
Lionakis services for LEED Silver design and certification  ADD $61,534
Total revised Lionakis contract value $989,165
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of Revision #001 to LIONAKIS PAA EVC-01 increasing the cost of design and construction phase services on the EVC Automotive Technology Project in the amount of $320,815.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Revision #01 to PAA EVC-01 with Lionakis increasing the cost of design and construction phase services on the EVC Automotive Technology Project in the amount of $320,815.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010: Revision #01 to Lionakis PAA EVC-01
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2010: Revision #01 to Lionakis PAA EVC-01

items.item_details:
Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) – Structure Consultants Group – EVC Central Plant & Police Station Renovation Inspector of Record (IOR) Services.
	 
In conjunction with the renovation and upgrade work associated with the EVC Central Plant and construction of the new Police Station, it is required by the Division of the State Architect (DSA) to provide DSA-approved inspection to ensure compliance with DSA requirements on the project.  Proposals were sought from the firms approved by the Board on August 14, 2012.  Four responses were received and based on those it is recommended that Structure Consultants Group be awarded a contract in the amount of $130,200 to act as the Inspector of Record for the Central Plant & Police Station Renovation project.
	 
The Board is asked to approve a contract to Structure Consultants Group in the amount of $130,200 for Inspector of Record services at the EVC-Central Plant and Police Station Renovation Project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a contract to Structures Consultants Group in the amount of $130,200 for Inspector of Record services at the EVC-Central Plant and Police Station Renovation Project.

items.item_details:
Contract â S&H Construction, Inc. â San Jose City College Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Upgrade Project Bid Package No. 1 
	 
Per the request of San Jose City College, the Program Manager initiated a public bidding process for contractors requesting proposals for San Jose City College Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Upgrade Project Bid Package No. 1. Bids were opened on March 26, 2013 and based on the evaluation of the bid prices and required documentation, S&H Construction, Inc. was the lowest responsive and responsible bidder to provide contracting services.
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a contract to S&H Construction, Inc. in the amount of $568,000 for the San Jose City College Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Upgrade Project Bid Package No. 1.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a contract to S&H Construction, Inc. in the amount of $568,000 for the San Jose City College Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Upgrade Project Bid Package No. 1.

items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2010: SJCC Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Upgrade Project Award

items.item_details:
Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) – Gilbane Building Company – Measure G-2004 Project Construction Management Services.
	 
The District and Colleges are pursuing a number of Measure G-2004 funded projects that are in need of construction management assistance:
	 
Joint Use 21st Century Education Center in Milpitas - In anticipation of a formal lease agreement between San Jose - Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) and Milpitas Unified School District (MUSD), SJECCD will need programming and construction project leadership and to facilitate the process for the District, to hire a consultant for the environmental approval process and to hire an architect for the initial programming of the future building. 
	 
Physical Education Building (SJCC) - LPAS Architecture has completed the necessary documents to establish the basis of design for the project (a key element to the selection of the design-build entity.)  The College has not been able to commit the level of resources required to develop and administer the selection process for the design-build entity.  The PE complex project has a direct impact on the Measure G 2010 bond and without support the delay of this project has a negative impact to the 2010 program and risks escalation costs associated with the delay.  This project will be a primary focus for Gilbane over the next few months.
	 
Miscellaneous Projects at EVC - EVC expects to hire design firms, consultants and construction services for various projects including security infrastructure, new structures for Grounds equipment and Warehouse, and new bleachers at the soccer athletic field. 
	 
Division of State Architect – DSA has contacted the District and identified seventeen completed projects that have not been closed out with their office.  In many cases the applications have been closed and must be reopened, additional fees paid, prior design firms contacted, old files researched and new applications with supporting documentation submitted.  Some of these open DSA projects will interfere with approval of applications for new projects (e.g. - Gullo at EVC, Autotech at EVC) and potentially create delays until they are satisfactorily closed out.
	 
Tasks to be performed by Gilbane in support of the Measure G-2004 program include making recommendations regarding necessary professional services to assist with closeout of open DSA applications, implement various projects, assist with procurement of consultants and contractors in coordination with District Purchasing, provide oversight of project design documents, provide oversight of bidding processes, provide oversight of project construction and assist with general Bond administration, accounting and regulatory approvals.
	 
To provide support for these projects, the District asked Gilbane to submit a proposal to provide dedicated staff for program support and construction management services on the work described above.  This proposal includes the cost for one full-time construction manager dedicated through the contract period (June 30, 2013.)  This contract will be funded using Measure G-2004 dollars. 
	 
Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010 are separate and distinct with separate accounts, projects, ballot language, etc.  It is anticipated that there will be a budget savings in the current contract funded by Measure G-2010 for Program/Construction Management Services that is greater than the new costs associated with this contract funded by Measure G-2004.  Given this, total compensation from both bond programs to Gilbane upon approval of this contract will not increase.
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a contract to GILBANE BUILDING COMPANY in the amount of $68,200 for Project Construction Management services in connection with Measure G-2004 Projects.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a contract to Gilbane Building Company in the amount of $68,200 to provide Project Construction Management services in connection with design, bidding and/or construction of Measure G-2004 Projects.

items.item_details:
Selection of Design-Build Delivery Method for Joint Use 21st Century Education Center in Milpitas and the 40 South Market Street District Office Building Renovations Projects.
	 
At the Board meeting held March 13, 2012 the Board was presented information and details by the Program Management team on alternative delivery methods including design-build. 
	 
Design-build is a qualifications-based selection process based on either a âpure qualifications-based selectionâ or a combination of qualifications and fees.  In this process a single entity (comprised of a builder and a design firm) provides design and construction.  In this process the design is carried by the District to bridging documents (similar to Design Development level documents), early selection of the design-build team based on those documents, and subsequently a project cost established by a Guaranteed Maximum Price.  Due to the nature of both the Milpitas project and the 40 South Market project, the design-build delivery is considered an optimum process to achieve District influence in the design, and achieve timely completion of the projects in a cost-effective manner.

items.item_details:
In response to an inquiry from the Board of Trustees regarding Bond Program information available on the internet, the Program Team will present a live demonstration of the Measures G-2004 and G-2010 Web Site.  This site directly contains or provides links to all primary information associated with the Bond Programs.  The site is aligned with Proposition 39 accountability standards and is randomly reviewed by the State of California’s Chancellor’s Office Facilities Planning Division for compliance. 
	 
To view this site directly, please go to http://cboc.sjebond.com/

items.item_details:
This report represents the status of schedule and cost for Measure G-2010 projects from inception through March 31, 2013, with financial data reconciled through December 31, 2012.
	 
The Schedule Status for four projects at San Jose City College has been changed to "CAUTION": These projects include:
	 
#31116 Campus Site Improvements
#31115 Theater Demo/ New Parking Lot
#31110 Utility Extension for New & Existing Buildings
#31114 Aux Gym, Pool & Locker Room 
	 
These four projects cannot start until the New Gym, a Measure G 2004 project, is complete. Delays in the New Gym project have pushed it to the point where it is now impacting the start of the four projects noted above. 
	 
The Schedule Status for two projects at Evergreen Valley College have also been changed to "CAUTION".
#32111 – Autotech – The schedule status for this project has been changed to “CAUTION” due to the addition of one month in the schematic design phase related to additional time to collect data related to the current facility. The project team and Program Manager anticipate that the final completion date for construction can be held and will be reflected in a subsequent report.
	 
#32108 – Administration and Student Services Remodel – The schedule status for this project has been changed to “CAUTION” due to the addition of one month in the programming phase to allow the design team to better assess the needs of Admissions & Records and to evaluate potential phasing of the work.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010: Summary Report March 2013
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010: Summary Report March 2013

items.item_details: The purpose of this presentation is to provide greater context to the Board of Trustees with regard to the vision, direction, process and progress of bond projects, and includes a review of the implementation of the San Jose City College Facilities Master Plan and the latest Project Update information as presented to the Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee on March 19, 2013.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010: San Jose City College Review of Facilities Master Plan & Project Updates
items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2010: San Jose City College Review of Facilities Master Plan & Project Updates

items.item_details:
As part of the ongoing 20% annual review and updating of Board Policies, Chapter 1, BP 1100 (The District) is submitted for first review by the Board of Trustees.  
	 
On March 21, 2013, the District Council recommended that the attached draft board policy be forwarded to the Chancellor and subsequently to the Board for review.  
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review the enclosed one-page board policy (BP 1100) which presentsâin table formâthe CCLC (Community College League of California) legal language, current SJECCD language and recommended changes per District Council to update this policy.  
	 
A recommendation for BP 1100 approval will take place at the next board meeting scheduled for May 13, 2013.
